--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kris Henderson" <khenderson@p...> 
wrote:
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@f...] 
<snip> 
> > I tend to like final on classes.
> 
> I read, I think it was in "Effective Java" that one should either 
design
> their classes to be extendable or prevent the class from being
> extendable.  So if you don't intend for your class to be extended 
then
> it should be declared to be final, have all the constructors 
private, or
> public constructors with final methods.  
> 

On the one hand I like things to be as private and final
as they can be. This means I don't have to search the
whole project for unexpected overrides and references
in order to understand something. (This tends
to be more a problem with inherited legacy code though).

On the other hand final makes the declaration a little bit
more cluttered so I don't always use it where I could. I
don't worry about restricting extendability since I can
always change it later

The original message about mocking final classes or
methods referred to the need to mock a class that you
cannot modify yourself. If I needed to mock a class
under my own control, I would probably introduce an
interface instead.

- Neil
